edu.asu.ying.mapreduce.rmi.activator

Interface Activator


  • public interface Activator
    Activator is the client node's entry point to remote method invocation on a server node.

    The Activator is a remote interface to a Remote reference factory.
    The remote activator is responsible for instantiating objects in the remote domain and returning remote references (proxy classes) to the caller.

    This is analogous to the Registry, but depends on injected factories on the remote side to provide the objects instead of maintaining a JVM-global registry.

    The activator is more similar to Microsoft's .NET Remoting Activator in that the server-side activator implementation draws its references from factories that may produce objects on the following bases:

    • Singleton
    • Client-Activated (active for the lifetime of the remote reference)
    • Single-Call (one instance per method invocation)

    Remote references are produced, for example, using java.rmi.server.UnicastRemoteObject#exportObject(Remote), but the actual method is implementation specific.

    Activator is a RemoteResource that can be located by a java.net.URI where the scheme is activator and the host is the implementation-specific host identifier.
    The authority part may be used by the implementing activator to apply authorization rules to object provisioning.
